STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 12, 2025
Aprille Sutton
Child & Family Services of Northwestern Michigan
3785 VETERANS DR,
TRAVERSE CITY, MI, 49684-4516
RE: License#: CB280201037
Dear Ms. Sutton:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
March 7, 2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 517-243-9743
Sincerely,
Douglas Turrill, Licensing Consultant
701 S. Elmwood
Traverse City MI. 49684
231-383-5531
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

Michigan

Applicants for adoption, Place children for
adoption, Place children in foster home,
Supervise Independent Living

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (1) An agency shall develop service plans with
the child, the child's parents or legal guardian,
the referring agency, and other parties involved
in providing needed services, or medical care,
unless the agency documents why any of the
entities have not been involved.
Five of eight files reviewed documented late or missing signatures on a PATP.
Repeat Violation:
03/1/2023 Renewal, CAP Approved 3/10/2023
02/29/24 Interim, CAP Approved 5/3/2024
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact
• (1) An agency shall develop a plan of visitation
and family time for each child in foster care
consistent with the child's service plans, as
required by R 400.12419 and R 400.12420 to
ensure the safety and well-being of the child.
Two of eight files reviewed each lacked in home visit narratives or the narratives
lacked comprehensiveness.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• The agency was informed that DCWL is no longer auditing any DHHS policy,
specifically the four areas that had remained until 10/1/24, Medical passports,
FTM's, the thirty day requirement for PATP signatures and all policy
requirements for in home case contacts. Signatures on PATP's are still
required under R 400.12418 (1) Development of service plans. In home
contacts still need to address the safety and well being of children as required
by R 400.12421 (1) Visitation and family time: in person contact.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was provided regarding safety alerts. An identified safety alert
requires the agency to generate a special evaluation to rectify the safety
concern. If a safety alert concern can be rectified at the time of the CPA
Analyst's visit to the home a special evaluation does not need to be initiated.
Placement of fire alarms was also discussed. Fire alarms must be placed
between the children's bedroom and the rest of the home and /or between the
master bedroom and the rest of the home.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
agency submitted an approved CAP on May 3, 2024, in response to those
violations established during the interim inspection completed on 2/29/24. During
the interim inspection the agency was cited for R 400.12413 Medical and Dental
policy, R 400.12418 Development of service plans, FOM 722-06B FTM's, and
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans. The current inspection established a repeat
violation for late or missing signatures on PATP's. The agency CAP of May 3,
2024, was successful in preventing repeat violations of the other three citations.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrators assessment was comprehensive and well written. The
assessment addressed the agency CAP from the 2024 Interim Inspection and the

agency's efforts to correct and prevent repeat violations. Efforts were
comprehensive in implementing the CAP and maintaining compliance with the
rules. The assessment also addressed barriers which included staff turnover and
staff illnesses during the fall and winter, Barriers also included increased worker
responsibilities as well as the CWLM system being cumbersome and time
consuming to work in. The agency also noted that it serves 17 counties which
creates extensive travel and time commitments. The assessment discussed
disrupted placements occurring in the agency ILP program.
Financial Overview
Financial records were reviewed which included the agency program budget as
well as a certified public accountant audit. No concerns were noted.
Staff Interviews
Staff reported enjoying working for the agency and the environment is supportive.
Staff reported feeling supported by their respective supervisors as well the agency
administration. Staff further reported the foster care and adoption teams work well
together.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency is located in a modern well equipped building in Traverse City. Office
space is sufficient. CHRI documents were observed to be secured.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The CPA Analyst identified six safety alerts during her visits to the homes. They are
as follows:
Safety Alert #1 The safety alert was generated on 12/23/24 as the home did not
have a smoke alarm between the basement bedroom and the rest of the home.
Resolution was achieved on 12/26/24. Photos of the installed fire alarm was
provided and uploaded.
Safety Alert #2. The safety alert was generated on 12/30/24 as the home was lacking
a fire alarm between the spare bedroom and the rest of the home.
Resolution was achieved on 1/2/25. Photos of the installed fire alarm was submitted
and uploaded.
Safety Alert #3. The safety alert was generated on 12/23/24. The home was missing
fire alarms in four different areas of the home, between the master bedroom and the
rest of the home, between the daughter’s bedroom and the rest of the home, two
bedroom entrances needing two alarms, and between the spare basement bedroom
and the rest of the home. The foster parent obtained fire alarms and stated that they
would install them upon returning from vacation.

Safety Alert # 4. This safety alert is a continuation of safety alert #3.
Resolution was obtained on 1/6/25 upon the families return from vacation. Photos
were submitted and uploaded.
Safety Alert #5. The safety alert was generated on 1/2/25 as the home was missing
two fire alarms, one between the master bedroom and the rest of the home and a
second between the children's bedroom and the rest of the home.
Resolution was achieved on 1/2/25, photos were submitted and uploaded.
Safety Alert #6. A safety alert was generated on 12/30/24 as the home was missing
a fire alarm between the master bedroom and the rest of the home.
Resolution was achieved on 1/3/25. Photos were submitted and uploaded.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
March 12, 2025
_____________________________________
Douglas Turrill Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
March 12, 2025
_____________________________________
Samantha Way Date
Area Manager
